docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Welcome to the official documentation for Aphril’s Widget Library.

Aphril’s Widget Library (AWL) is a style-agnostic, material-driven UI system built around modular composition, procedural flexibility, and production-ready efficiency—so teams can ship polished interfaces without building a widget library from scratch.

Technical documentation for all products can be found using the navigation on the left.

docs.title: Basic Installation
docs.text:
1. Enable the plugin:
  2. Either add it directly to your .uproject file's "Plugins" section, 
        {

      "Name": "AphrilsWidgetLibraryButtons",
      "Enabled": true,
      "MarketplaceURL": "https://www.fab.com/sellers/Silverkeep%20Studios%20-%20Aphril",
      "SupportedTargetPlatforms": [ "Win64", "Linux" ]

    }

or

  1. Enable it through the editor:

  2. Edit → Plugins → Enable Aphrils Widget Library - Buttons

  3. Enable plugin content visibility:

  4. Open the Content Drawer
  5. Click the gear icon (top-right)
  6. Enable Show Plugin Content

docs.title: If you cannot see your plugin in the content drawer after enabling plugin visibility:
docs.text: Your plugin is likely installed as an engine plugin. Enabling engine content will let you view the plugin from the content drawer. Content Drawer Settings → Check "Engine Content" You should now see your plugin in the engine folder in your content drawer, but this isn't ideal because there are a large number of engine plugins.

docs.title: Recommended: Install the plugin in your project
docs.text:
This will give you easier access to your plugin based content.

To get your plugin from the engine installation:

  1. In editor select Edit → Plugins
  2. Search "Aphrils Widget Library - Buttons"
  3. Select package
  4. Pick an output folder that is easy to get to.
  5. Navigate to the packaged plugin output
  6. Depending on how the output was packaged:
  7. If it is packaged in a host project copy the plugin("AphrilsWidgetLibraryButtons" folder) from the plugins directory.
  8. If it is just the plugin copy the plugin "AphrilsWidgetLibraryButtons" folder
  9. You can know you have the right folder copied because inside it there will be a "AphrilsWidgetLibraryButtons.uplugin" file inside it.
  10. Now that we have the plugin, we can install it in your project but copying the plugin folder into your "ProjectFolder/Plugins"
  11. Build your project to ensure the plugin is built.
  12. Enable the plugin in Edit → Plugins → Aphril's Widget Library - Buttons
  13. You should now be able to see the plugin in your Content Drawer in the "Plugins" folder.

docs.title: Recommended: Project Setup
docs.text:
1. In Project/Content, create the following folders:
  2. WidgetLibrary

  3. WidgetLibrary/Buttons

  4. Use these folders for:

  5. User-owned Material Instances
  6. Widget Blueprints
  7. Common UI styles

This keeps project-specific customization cleanly separated from plugin content.

docs.title: Optional: Verification Steps
docs.text:
1. In the Content Drawer, right-click and select: User Interface → Widget Blueprint

  2. Open the newly created Widget Blueprint

  3. In the Palette, locate Aphril’s Widget Library (Defaults to the upper center-left area of the palette)

  4. You should see five buttons available

  5. Try out your new buttons.

  6. You can also see all buttons at once though Plugins → "Aphril's Widget Library - Buttons" → Showcase

  7. Right click WBP_Showcase → Preview

Now that you are all setup Installation-Wise our Workflow Guide can help you get to know your new content.

If you are having technical issues with the installation you can create a Support Ticket for assistance.
Initial Release
Added in 4 new use gradient parameters which allow gradients to be disabled, inverted, or displayed at different strengths. Fixed an issue where sometimes the body horizonal gradient wouldn't work.

docs.title: Glow
docs.text: Parameter Type Description Body Inner Glow Intensity Scalar Strungth of the of radial gradient which applied to the center of the body. Positive is a Dodge, legative is a burn. Used for Hover effects. Body Inner Glow Radius Scalar Radius of radial gradient which applied to the center of the body. Positive is a Dodge, legative is a burn. Used for Hover effects.

docs.title: Gradient
docs.text: Parameter Type Description Use Border Horizontal Gradient Scalar Whether or not to apply a border horizontal gradient. 0 use none, 1 use all, inbetween use some. Use Border Vertical Gradient Scalar Whether or not to apply a border vertical gradient. 0 use none, 1 use all, inbetween use some. Play with this and the other use gradient params. You can create tons of different gradients types by moving the values around. docs.title: How to Channel-Pack Textures in Krita
docs.text:
In Krita you can easily pack a layered image into the appropriate R,G,B channels

Setup your image with the following layers for packing: - Border - Body - Opacity

Warning : Copy Red, Copy Green, Copy Blue filters are often used for channel packing in Krita, but they can be a bit finicky, luckily Krita offers us a better way to pack our textures.

For each layer:

  1. In the layers docker (Default Center-Right of your screen in Krita 5)
  2. Right-Click the layer you would like to assign to be packed into a channel.
  3. Select Properties
  4. In the active channels deselect the channels you do not want to pack from the layer.
  5. E.g. For packing the Border layer into the red channel only red should be selected.
  6. Repeat this for all layers you wish to pack. You can also pack multiple layers into the same channel.
  7. Disable visibility on all layers you do not want to pack, ensure visibility on all layers you want to pack. (Eye icon for each layer)
  8. Export your texture:
  9. File → Export → File Type: Png → Save
  10. When selecting compression and save file settings, uncheck "Store Alpha Channel" this will premultiply the alpha to our R,G, B channels and save us space
  11. If you do not uncheck the "Store Alpha Channel" your image may have blocky-ness when you import it into ue. This is because we do not use the Alpha channel and if the alpha isn't premultiplied in if the RGB Channels are spotless when you export they will come out jagged because the alpha hasn't cleaned them up.

docs.title: Tips for Creating Themes That Vary Drastically from Default Themes
Sci-Fi Theme
docs.text:
• Use thin borders on shapes (1–4 px).
  • Keep shapes flat—avoid bevels, satin layers, or other depth effects.

  • For slight transparency, use a gray opacity mask:

    • ~70% gray for high opacity
    • ~90% gray for subtle translucency
    • Apply noise texture intensity modulation to break up gradient banding.
    • Use a plain background texture for digital display–style buttons.

docs.title: Flat Theme
docs.text:
• Create shapes similar to the default button shapes.
  • Avoid all depth effects such as bevel or satin layers.

docs.title: Parchment Theme
docs.text:
• Edges: Make slightly frayed.
  • Use a small border or no border at all.
  • Apply a parchment-style background.
  • Use a stencil for inlaid designs on the parchment.
  • For a grunge/frayed edges effect, use a grunge brush to tweak opacity. Example Tutorial

docs.title: Recommended Workflow
docs.text: This workflow shows how to create custom-styled buttons using Aphril’s Widget Library while preserving built-in animations and default behavior.

docs.title: 1. Prepare a Material Instance
docs.text:
1. Duplicate a Material Instance from the plugin.
  2. Move it into:
WidgetLibrary/Buttons
  1. Adjust the material instance to match your preferred visual style.

docs.title: 2. Duplicate a Button Widget
docs.text:
1. Duplicate a HexButton (or any other button type) from the plugin.
  2. Move the duplicated widget into:
WidgetLibrary/Buttons

docs.title: 3. Update Variable Default Values
docs.text:
1. Open your duplicated button in the Widget Blueprint Editor.
  2. Switch to the Event Graph tab.
  3. In the Variables panel (left side), expand the Appearance category.
  4. Select the Button Image variable.

Tip: If the Details panel is not visible, enable it via Window → Details

  1. In the Details panel for Button Image:

    • Set Default Value → Button Image
    • Assign your configured Material Instance from WidgetLibrary/Buttons

  2. Verify that your button now displays the new style.

Your newly themed button will appear under Aphril’s Widget Library in the Widget Palette.

docs.title: Optional: Add Your Button to the Common UI Category
docs.text:
By default, user-created widgets appear under Common UI. To place your button there:

  1. Open your button widget.
  2. From the top menu, select File → Reparent Blueprint
  3. Choose CommonButtonBase

docs.title: Advanced: Create Your Own Palette Category
docs.text:
If you want full control over how widgets are grouped in the Widget Palette:

  1. Use UAwlMaterialButton as the base for a new C++ class.
  2. Give the class a unique name to avoid One Definition Rule (ODR) conflicts.
  3. Override GetPaletteCategory() to return your desired category name.
  4. Reparent any widgets you want in this category to your new class.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
This duplication-based workflow provides a strong default setup that includes:

  • Built-in animations
  • All AWL default behavior
  • Instance-editable and spawn-exposed properties

This allows you to:

  • Customize styling, button images, text styling, and text per widget
  • Adjust defaults by editing variable default values
  • Modify buttons directly inside UMG Widget Blueprints (e.g., menus and UI screens)

docs.title: Why this works well
docs.text:
• You retain all plugin functionality without modifying plugin assets
  • Updates to the plugin won’t overwrite your custom buttons
  • Styling and behavior remain centralized and reusable

docs.title: About
docs.text:
Aphril’s Widget Library (AWL) is a line of widgets for Unreal Engine 5.

The goal of Aphril’s Widget Library is to provide creators with a modular library of flexible, configurable, high-quality widgets needed to build user interfaces quickly and efficiently.

AWL widgets are designed to integrate cleanly into your existing game UI design, providing high-quality, configurable procedural effects, animations, and theming. This allows your team to focus on building the game itself rather than creating a complete widget library from scratch.

In addition to procedural effects, AWL uses a thoughtful texture stack that allows users to apply a variety of texture-based effects—such as grunge, background, noise, and stencils—to their widgets.

All widgets are built using a hybrid grayscale texture and parameterized material approach, allowing materials to be easily tuned to match the desired visual style of the project.

This approach enables maximum stylistic flexibility. You can:

  • Retheme any widget by adjusting material colors
  • Modify animations by manipulating material parameters in Sequencer
  • Control styling for every widget using the full flexibility of Common UI styles
  • Change the overall feel of widgets by swapping textures (grunge, noise, background, stencils) and adjusting their intensity
  • Create entirely new widget styles by supplying custom grayscale shape textures

docs.title: Product Design Pillars
docs.text: These are the four pillars that guide our product design.

docs.title: Design Excellence
docs.text:
• Every product is documented extensively
  • All parameters are categorized, include descriptions and defaults, and are clamped to sane input ranges
  • All code follows SOLID design principles
  • Every product goes through multiple QA passes before being listed

docs.title: Style-Agnostic by Design
docs.text:
AWL widgets are built to adapt to your game’s visual language, not impose their own.

  • Hybrid grayscale textures and parameterized materials form the foundation
  • Retheming is handled through materials, styles, and parameters—not asset replacement
  • Texture stacks (grunge, noise, background, stencils) reduce custom art requirements

docs.title: Material-Driven Flexibility
docs.text:
Visual behavior is controlled through materials and parameters, not hardcoded logic or baked assets.

  • All visual properties are animatable via Sequencer
  • Effect intensity, textures, and colors are fully exposed and tunable
  • Procedural effects live in materials, not Blueprint logic

docs.title: Composable, Modular Architecture
docs.text:
Widgets are building blocks, not sealed products.

  • Designed to slot cleanly into existing UIs
  • Modular structure supports reparenting, extension, and recomposition
  • Common UI styles are treated as first-class citizens
  • Encourages reuse, consistency, and rapid iteration
